details.description: A study of body-culture-watershed as studio.
details.name: Eno River Project

modules.text:
Clay jars are the watershed between nomadic hunter gatherer and the agrarian then urban march to civilization. The ability to warehouse water, seed or btu's or KwH's for a time of future need have been the currency that buys creative human expression in all its forms.
 
By boiling this jar one can reclaim both wax and clay for larger and more refined applications. The waxed clay can be composted, effecting a soil remediation through the nutritive content of the beeswax.
 
For the exhibition in Hillsborough I delivered this jar the 12 miles to the gallery by boat on the Eno River and its tributaries, and foot, carrying the boat over land for 3 miles from my studio to reach the nearest marginally navigable waterway, Crabtree Creek. My meditative intent was to carry the weight of that watershed moment in which our predecessors first achieved warehousing of surplus and its subsequent urbanity.
 
To that end, the proportional relationships are carefully considered. The jar weighs an estimated fifty pounds empty and holds an estimated twelve gallons of water. At just over eight pounds to the gallon, the water weight of this jar's volumetric capacity is 100 pounds. 150 pounds is the approximate average weight of an adult human worldwide. Two thirds of human body weight is water.
 
My interest in a reductive art grows from the silent service of my Quaker upbringing. Silence is a stripping away of distractions from the light within but it is not an absence of sound. Buckminster Fuller used to say that everything living is sunlight bound into matter. The bee's wax is a potent concentration of the nectar flowering plants produce to attract pollinators- the energy bound up in this wax is sunlight. According to Fuller this jar is a vessel of light. According to the Quakers, so am I.
 
Jars exist as primary documents in the anthropological record. While organic sealants have been used for vessels in the past for both decorative and functional applications, beeswax is unusual especially in contemporary studio ceramics. One of the delightful discoveries during this jar's (and my own) journey to the gallery comes from the need to roll the jar for portions of the overland route. The jar gathered wax impressions where rocks and sticks touched it. It is a form of wax cylinder recording of its own journey. Like a wax cylinder, we cannot “read” the recording without appropriate audio equipment. The jar is the only physical record of its own journey. All other information is available only as long as this printed text, those I have told the story to, or I myself, the “audio equipment” if you will, remain alive. This exhibition is an annotated oral narrative.
 
My present moment is the interface of how this jar came to be as you see it before you and of what its role will be after its useful life as a container is over. My work is its own most fleeting and least useful state.
 
 
 
Jordan Taylor
Hillsborough, NC
2010

details.description: Using the game of chess as a starting off point, I created a chess club in the heart of downtown Providence that mutates the way players play and interact with one another.
details.name: Mind Games

modules.text:
Fall 2012:  5 Week Project
106 Eddy St, Providence RI
 
Asked to convert the ground floor and basement of a neighboring building into a local chess club, the project started with an analysis of the game.  Concepts arose from the chess analysis which were then implemented into the final design.
modules.text_plain:
Fall 2012:  5 Week Project

106 Eddy St, Providence RI

 

Asked to convert the ground floor and basement of a neighboring building into a local chess club, the project started with an analysis of the game.  Concepts arose from the chess analysis which were then implemented into the final design.

modules.text: The site was located between two parallel major roads.  Situated on a corner that led into a utility alley, we were permitted to venture out of the building and occupy the alley.  The site is visible from Weybosset St across a parking lot.
modules.text_plain: The site was located between two parallel major roads.  Situated on a corner that led into a utility alley, we were permitted to venture out of the building and occupy the alley.  The site is visible from Weybosset St across a parking lot.

modules.text:
The project was started with an analyisis of the game of chess.  We were asked to create a 3d diagram that depicted 4 consecutive moves of three assigned pieces (I was given pawn, knight, rook).
From my diagrams and anyalysis led me to a discovery - whenever pieces occupied the same space there was a moment of intersection that led to mutation.
modules.text_plain:
The project was started with an analyisis of the game of chess.  We were asked to create a 3d diagram that depicted 4 consecutive moves of three assigned pieces (I was given pawn, knight, rook).

From my diagrams and anyalysis led me to a discovery - whenever pieces occupied the same space there was a moment of intersection that led to mutation.

modules.text:
Translating the idea of intersection/mutation into the space, I started with the idea of the floor mutating into a ramp where the axis of the two floors met.  The idea of mutation, however, wasn't strong enough with just a ramp so I started folding paper.  From there I discovered that the reason folded paper was a stronger mutation was for two reasons:
1 - You could clrealy see what the paper was before.
2 - The folding followed a clear, repetivtive set of rules in mutating.
 
I took what I learned from the paper folding to mutate the ramp further into a playing field.
modules.text_plain:
Translating the idea of intersection/mutation into the space, I started with the idea of the floor mutating into a ramp where the axis of the two floors met.  The idea of mutation, however, wasn't strong enough with just a ramp so I started folding paper.  From there I discovered that the reason folded paper was a stronger mutation was for two reasons:

1 - You could clrealy see what the paper was before.

2 - The folding followed a clear, repetivtive set of rules in mutating.

 

I took what I learned from the paper folding to mutate the ramp further into a playing field.

modules.text: Working in a machine shop, I found many discarded CNC cutouts of 6061 Aluminum. Taking advantage of the beautifully milled surface, I created this TIG welded polished Aluminum smartphone stand, dubbed "The Lean-Two".
modules.text_plain: Working in a machine shop, I found many discarded CNC cutouts of 6061 Aluminum. Taking advantage of the beautifully milled surface, I created this TIG welded polished Aluminum smartphone stand, dubbed "The Lean-Two".

details.description: A sereis of four ton ceramic components are fabricated, assembled, and installed in perpetuity. Their fired porosity allows them to erode, releasing the material down the watershed to the mouth of the Susquehanna River where the clay was mined.
details.name: Stele Project: Everhart Museum

modules.text:
Mud Man, Fire Man
 
Jordan Taylor jokingly suggested when
we were first in contact that I might dismiss him as one of Bernard Leach’s
orphans, perhaps my most infamous line. And yes, Taylor began as a
traditionalist, but he is also a modernist, or in my terms, a neo-classicist.
Journeys into the traditional kingdom of clay are often narrow, blinkered
experiences, heavy on the mud but light on the deeper, more complex,
multifaceted interactions that make up a creative odyssey. Its not that these
interactions do not exist in the pots, just that a lot of traditional potters do
not have Taylor's kind of analytical curiosity and so their love of clay can become
an adobe prison. That said I have not come across a better piece of writing on
the expansiveness of neo-classicist values than in this publication nor a more
beautiful expression of traditional clay-and-fire virtues in contemporary
process art.
 
Taylor’s essay moves gently through place, time, and above all, mind,
inspired by the El Mirador Mayan ruins he visited on a trip to Guatemala. En
route Taylor cites ceramic heroes such as Michael Cardew and Robert Turner
but also enlists a less obvious gang of modernists, John Cage, Merce 
Cunningham, Dan Flavin, Robert Morris and David Smith. His experiences
drive Taylor inexorably towards a destination that was not clear early on, a
large-scale public installation of four, six-foot (1.8m) four-ton (4000kg) stelae
in a park near his studio. Given their porosity, estimated at 6-8%, they will
slowly erode “and follow the watershed as far as the Chesapeake Bay, back to
the lie of the land.”
 
Taylor’s love of clay is palpable, almost religious, and it is interesting
because it is not based on what comes out of a pug mill; rather, it is more
about an existential view of clay and its place, literally, in the greater world. He
cites a paragraph from Bernard Leach’s foreword to Michael Cardew’s book
Pioneer Pottery as an early inspiration: “Cardew has spent years under a
kerosene lamp at night in the African tropics, sweating at his geology and
chemistry in order, literally, to understand the lie of his land; to find and to be
able to use intelligently the rocks and clays, ashes and oxides with which…
pots are made.”
 
He responded in 1996 by making “several hundred glaze line blends
using clays I had dug, and wood ashes. Underlying that research were
ambitions that I no longer hold exclusively: my goal was to make serviceable
glazes from indigenous materials. I’ve since reversed this relationship. What I
make while exploring a new clay is my response to a clay’s material and firing
properties, rather than shaping clay to execute a plan”.
 
But clay does not dominate. Cardew liked to say that in ceramics there
were two kinds of makers, mud people and fire people. (He identified with the
former and had a very ambivalent, adversarial relationship with the kiln).
While his generalization is correct as defining two distant poles, in-between
there are multiple combinations of the two. My guess is that when Taylor’s
hands touch new raw clay his first thought might well be, “What will this
make?” But simultaneously the sensual stuff between his fingers excites
another question, “What kind of fire will memorialize its life?” In this case he
chose a firing that allowed the clay its gradual mortality. The same objective
humanism pervades all of this project.
 
Garth Clark
Santa Fe 2010

Mud Man, Fire Man

 

Jordan Taylor jokingly suggested when

we were first in contact that I might dismiss him as one of Bernard Leach’s

orphans, perhaps my most infamous line. And yes, Taylor began as a

traditionalist, but he is also a modernist, or in my terms, a neo-classicist.

Journeys into the traditional kingdom of clay are often narrow, blinkered

not have Taylor's kind of analytical curiosity and so their love of clay can become

an adobe prison. That said I have not come across a better piece of writing on

in a park near his studio. Given their porosity, estimated at 6-8%, they will

slowly erode “and follow the watershed as far as the Chesapeake Bay, back to

the lie of the land.”

able to use intelligently the rocks and clays, ashes and oxides with which…

pots are made.”

ambitions that I no longer hold exclusively: my goal was to make serviceable

chose a firing that allowed the clay its gradual mortality. The same objective

humanism pervades all of this project.

 

Garth Clark

Santa Fe 2010

details.description: Using a small box, create a space that depicts a given mood/feeling.
details.name: Mood in a Box

modules.text:
Can space capture the essence of a feeling? We utilize adjective like somber, delicate, rational, etc to describe the character of spaces on a day to day basis. It is an intuitive process we engage with.
 
The challenge for this project was to begin with the mood and create a space from there. Given basic achromatic materials and predetermined dimensions to work with I was assigned three adjectives: happy, disorienting, and otherworldly. I chose to work with happy and otherworldly and then utilized light, form and texture to imbue the space with those traits.
modules.text_plain: Can space capture the essence of a feeling? We utilize adjective like somber, delicate, rational, etc to describe the character of spaces on a day to day basis. It is an intuitive process we engage with. The challenge for this project was to begin with the mood and create a space from there. Given basic achromatic materials and predetermined dimensions to work with I was assigned three adjectives: happy, disorienting, and otherworldly. I chose to work with happy and otherworldly and then utilized light, form and texture to imbue the space with those traits.

details.description: This is a widget/function concept embedded into the digital map such as Google Maps. By clicking the weather button, users can activate the weather filter function. People can modify seasons, weather conditions, where it is day or night and the temperature range to filter pictures of places.
details.name: Google Maps Weather Filter Concept

modules.text: Weather Maps is a widget/function concept embedded into Google Maps. By clicking the weather button, users can activate the weather filter function.
modules.text_plain: Weather Maps is a widget/function concept embedded into Google Maps. By clicking the weather button, users can activate the weather filter function.

modules.text: You can modify seasons, weather conditions, where it is day or night and the temperature range to filter pictures of places.
modules.text_plain: You can modify seasons, weather conditions, where it is day or night and the temperature range to filter pictures of places.

modules.text: You also can turn on the temperature button to let the photo display the temperature parameters in a small icon located in the corner of the photo.
modules.text_plain: You also can turn on the temperature button to let the photo display the temperature parameters in a small icon located in the corner of the photo.

modules.text: When people click a specific photo, they also can press the “weather icon” in each picture to see the photos of the place in various weather conditions.
modules.text_plain: When people click a specific photo, they also can press the “weather icon” in each picture to see the photos of the place in various weather conditions.

details.description:
2013 
Appropriated images, paper 

Journey to the West appropriates images collected from the internet and reformats them into a three-dimensional collage. Using my own personal experience as a starting point, it is a representation of an online culture which is based in the approximate, filtered understanding of existing cultures offline. The title - based off the a classic Chinese novel about a Buddhist pilgrimage - is a reference to the transfer of Eastern entertainment culture to Western countries. My goal was to use these images to portray a slice of that online culture in a way that indicates its own existence... Not to portray it as its most well-known stereotypes or tropes, but as its own entity as it manifests itself in the identities of its participants. 

This piece was exhibited in ALL THAT GLITTERS IS NOT LEDS, the RISD digital+media biennial in Providence, RI in 2013.
details.name: Journey to the West
